The product of the factors is the original number

type: ∀ (n : ℕ+), PrimeMultiset.prod (PNat.factorMultiset n) = n
name: PNat.prod_factorMultiset
docString: The product of the factors is the original number

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

A product of finite numbers is still finite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {R : Type u_8} [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] [inst_1 : NoZeroDivisors R] [inst_2 : Nontrivial R]
  [inst_3 : DecidableEq R] [inst_4 : LT R] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop R},
  (∀ i ∈ s, f i ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.prod s fun i => f i) < ⊤
name: WithTop.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite

For any category with binary products, the product of two objects exists.

type:
∀ {C : Type u_2} [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{u_1, u_2} C] [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Limits.HasBinaryProducts C]
  (X Y : C), CategoryTheory.Limits.HasLimit (CategoryTheory.Limits.pair X Y)
name: CategoryTheory.Limits.prod.functor.proof_1
docString: For any category with binary products, the product of two objects exists.

This theorem states that for any list of positive numbers in a strictly ordered semiring (a type of algebraic structure that includes operations analogous to addition and multiplication), the product of all numbers in the list is also positive. This theorem applies to any list of positive natural numbers and can be extended to any nontrivial ordered semiring.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : StrictOrderedSemiring R] (l : List R), (∀ a ∈ l, 0 < a) → 0 < l.prod
name: List.prod_pos
docString: This theorem states that for any list of positive numbers in a strictly ordered semiring (a type of algebraic structure that includes operations analogous to addition and multiplication), the product of all numbers in the list is also positive. This theorem applies to any list of positive natural numbers and can be extended to any nontrivial ordered semiring.

name: Profinite.NobelingProof.GoodProducts
docString: The set of good products.

the image of a product is less or equal than the sum of the images.

type:
∀ {F : Type u_7} {α : outParam (Type u_8)} {β : outParam (Type u_9)} [inst : Mul α] [inst_1 : Add β] [inst_2 : LE β]
  [self : MulLEAddHomClass F α β] (f : F) (a b : α), f (a * b) ≤ f a + f b
name: MulLEAddHomClass.map_mul_le_add
docString: the image of a product is less or equal than the sum of the images.

A product is regular if and only if the factors are.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommSemigroup R] {a b : R}, IsRegular (a * b) ↔ IsRegular a ∧ IsRegular b
name: isRegular_mul_iff
docString: A product is regular if and only if the factors are.

A list with product less than one must have positive length.

type: ∀ {M : Type u_3} [inst : Monoid M] [inst_1 : Preorder M] (L : List M), List.prod L < 1 → 0 < List.length L

name: List.length_pos_of_one_lt_prod
docString: A list with product greater than one must have positive length.

Binary products are symmetric.

type:
{C : Type u} →
  [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{v, u} C] →
    {X Y : C} →
      {c : CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan X Y} →
        CategoryTheory.Limits.IsLimit c →
          CategoryTheory.Limits.IsLimit
            (CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.mk (CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.snd c)
              (CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.fst c))
name: CategoryTheory.Limits.BinaryFan.isLimitFlip
docString: Binary products are symmetric.

the image of a product is less or equal than the product of the images.

type:
∀ {F : Type u_7} {α : outParam (Type u_8)} {β : outParam (Type u_9)} [inst : NonUnitalNonAssocRing α]
  [inst_1 : OrderedSemiring β] [self : RingSeminormClass F α β] (f : F) (a b : α), f (a * b) ≤ f a * f b
name: RingSeminormClass.map_mul_le_mul
docString: the image of a product is less or equal than the product of the images.

If a product lies in the prime ideal, then at least one element lies in the prime ideal.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Semiring α] {I : Ideal α} [self : Ideal.IsPrime I] {x y : α}, x * y ∈ I → x ∈ I ∨ y ∈ I
name: Ideal.IsPrime.mem_or_mem'
docString: If a product lies in the prime ideal, then at least one element lies in the prime ideal.

The pullback over the zero object is the product.

type:
{C : Type u_1} →
  [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{u_2, u_1} C] →
    [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Limits.HasZeroObject C] →
      [inst_2 : CategoryTheory.Limits.HasZeroMorphisms C] →
        (X Y : C) → [inst_3 : CategoryTheory.Limits.HasBinaryProduct X Y] → CategoryTheory.Limits.pullback 0 0 ≅ X ⨯ Y
name: CategoryTheory.Limits.pullbackZeroZeroIso
docString: The pullback over the zero object is the product.

Taking duals distributes over products.

type:
(R : Type uR) →
  (M : Type uM) →
    [inst : CommSemiring R] →
      [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid M] →
        [inst_2 : Module R M] →
          (M' : Type uM') →
            [inst_3 : AddCommMonoid M'] →
              [inst_4 : Module R M'] → (Module.Dual R M × Module.Dual R M') ≃ₗ[R] Module.Dual R (M × M')
name: Module.dualProdDualEquivDual
docString: Taking duals distributes over products.

docString: Type product is associative up to an equivalence.

The inner product is positive definite.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_4} {F : Type u_5} [inst : IsROrC 𝕜] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup F] [inst_2 : Module 𝕜 F]
  (self : InnerProductSpace.Core 𝕜 F) (x : F), ⟪x, x⟫_𝕜 = 0 → x = 0
name: InnerProductSpace.Core.definite
docString: The inner product is positive definite.

The product over `Fin 2` of some rings is just the cartesian product of these rings.

type: (R : Fin 2 → Type u_1) → [inst : (i : Fin 2) → Semiring (R i)] → ((i : Fin 2) → R i) ≃+* R 0 × R 1
name: RingEquiv.piFinTwo
docString: The product over `Fin 2` of some rings is just the cartesian product of these rings.
